metadata.case_name: Appellants v. State of Andhra Pradesh

facts.text: Local police took cognizance of a serious occurrence of rioting with murder on December 22, 1955.
Local police investigated the case, recorded evidence, and submitted a charge-sheet under ss. 147, 148, 323, 324 and 302 read with ss. 34 and 149 IPC to the magistrate.
Magistrate, following procedure in s. 207A CrPC, committed the 26 accused persons (appellants) to the Court of Session, Guntur Division, for trial.
Accused filed applications in revision under ss. 435 and 439 CrPC to the High Court of Andhra Pradesh to quash the commitment order, arguing s. 207A unconstitutional.
High Court (Krishna Rao J.) dismissed the revisions on September 28, 1956, holding provisions constitutional and commitment valid.
High Court granted certificate under Art. 134(1)(c) Constitution for appeal to Supreme Court.
Union of India intervened as provisions of Central Act impugned.

legal_issues.text: Constitutionality of ss. 207 and 207A CrPC (introduced by Act XXVI of 1955), whether they introduce discrimination violating Art. 14 Constitution by prescribing less advantageous procedure for cases on police report compared to other cases.

petitioner_arguments.text: Ss. 207 and 207A provide two separate procedures for commitment: s. 207A for police report cases is less advantageous to accused than procedure in other provisions of Chapter XVIII.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: ss. 207A(2), 207A(4), absence of provisions corresponding to ss. 208(3), 208(1), 209(2), 213(2), 215 CrPC; ss. 162, 215 CrPC; ss. 27, 101-106, 114(g) Evidence Act; Art. 14 Constitution

petitioner_arguments.text: Illustrations of disadvantage: no power for accused to summon witnesses (s. 207A(2) vs s. 208(3)); only prosecution evidence referenced (s. 207A(4) vs s. 208(1)); no discharge powers (no equiv to s. 209(2), 213(2)); 'no grounds' vs 'no sufficient grounds' (s. 207A(6) vs s. 209(1)); deprived of benefits under ss. 162, 215 CrPC and Evidence Act sections.

respondent_arguments.text: Provisions constitutional; differences not prejudicial; aim to simplify and expedite procedure.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Act XXVI of 1955; established classifications in CrPC based on gravity of offences, cognizable/non-cognizable, etc.

court_reasoning.text: Assumes differences in procedures but not always to disadvantage of accused; amendments by Act XXVI 1955 simplify and expedite commitment in police-investigated cases.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Code always prescribes different procedures based on gravity of offences, cognizable nature, etc.; classification reasonable.

court_reasoning.text: In police report cases (cognizable serious offences), state duty to prosecute speedily; s. 207A ensures expeditious trial without unnecessary facilities that prolong process.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Elaborate procedure retained for complaint cases to guard against private vendetta.

court_reasoning.text: No change in trial procedure post-commitment; classification based on prior police investigation vs complaint has rational nexus to object of speedy justice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art. 14 permits reasonable classification with intelligible differentia and nexus to legislative object.

court_reasoning.text: Applies test from Budhan Choudhry: classification founded on whether police charge-sheet submitted; promotes speedy trial.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No discrimination; procedure under s. 207A in interest of accused if innocent, to clear name early.

holdings.text: Ss. 207 and 207A CrPC constitutional; no violation of Art. 14 as classification reasonable with nexus to speedy trial.

precedents_cited.relevance: Nearest case; upheld s.30 CrPC classification; Art.14 test of reasonable classification
Upheld s.197 CrPC; discretionary power not necessarily discriminatory

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Impugned provisions for commitment procedures; police investigation and trial processes

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding the constitutionality of ss. 207 and 207A CrPC and validity of the commitment order.

key_quotes.text: The only question that arises for determination in this appeal... is the constitutionality of the provisions of ss. 207 and 207A, Code of Criminal Procedure.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: While article 14 forbids class legislation, it does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key test from Budhan Choudhry applied

key_quotes.text: There cannot be the least doubt that the Legislature has been well-advised to amend the procedure relating to commitment proceedings in cases which have been investigated by a competent police officer.
key_quotes.speaker: court
